Defining each liquid species as a stoichiometric liquid is not want  
you want to do.  This will give you 40 separate fixed-composition  
liquid phases. What you want is a single liquid phase solution of 40  
species. Harry Moffat has added classes for liquid solutions to  
Cantera, so he is probably the best one to answer this.  But  
unfortunately the hooks to access these classes from Python or MATLAB  
have not been implemented yet, so you are likely to need to work in C+ 
+ to use these...


On Jan 25, 2007, at 10:44 AM, chitral_naik wrote:

> Hello,
>
> I am trying to solve three phase equilibrium at 1 atm and 350K. My gas
> phase species (idealgas mix) involve combustion products and halogens.
> There are more than 40 species in liquid phase (I had to define each
> as stoichiometric liquid) and about 10 solid phase species (each
> defined as stoichiometric solid).
>
> When I use multiphase equilibrium, the answer is different from that
> from popular HSC Chemistry 5.1 program. Has anyone encountered this
> problem? Please let me know if you have successfully used a three
> phase equilibrium solver and compared to HSC or other multiphase
> equilibrium solvers.
>
> My code uses 'importPhases'and Mixture(phases) to import all phases
> and species.
>
> Thank you,
> Chitral
>
